page on Duties of a Recruit

The Recruit is in training to become a Deputy. The period lasts a month, and during this month the recruit proves himself worthy of becoming a full member of the Constabulary.
During the time the recruit assists a full member of the Constabulary, who acts as his Mentor. The recruit aids with investigations, filing crimes, capturing criminals and keeping law and order.
Duties
~Learn the laws of Triskellian and the duties of being part of the Constabulary
~Assist with arresting wanted criminals and bring them to the goal
~Create new @crime files once his Mentor deems him ready
~Assist in ongoing investigations
~Help maintain law and order
~Patrol Docktown
~Feed prisoners
Is given
~Lessons from the guild teacher
~Lessons from other Constabulary members

page on Code of Conduct

As a recruit for the Constabulary there are several things to keep in mind and be aware of.
The most important points are:
Know the law and the different type of charges which can be made. This is the most important part as our job is to enforce and uphold the law in Triskellian.
~The law can be found publicly for all to read. Make sure you know it by heart. [ooc: http://forum.skotos.net/showthread.php?t=80797]
~Be aware of your responsibility to file any crime that you come across, or that anyone asks you to file. Even if you know it might not be as they say. Subsequent investigation will determine what's right and wrong.
~Should someone report a crime that you know is wrong and done by someone else, you file their report, and can file your own subsequently.
~Remember that you always represent the Crown and the Constabulary. Both privately and publicly. How you behave will reflect not only upon yourself, but also on the Constabulary, thereby eventually the Crown.
~Always be polite and proper. Greet all the same, showing proper respect for rank. Even those you suspect of crimes you show basic courtesy in public. Do not let your behaviour tarnish that of the Constabulary.

page on Code of Conduct continued

~Do not associate with unsavoury elements. People who're known criminals, suspected of crimes or in general disfavoured by Crown or Constabulary. In particular this is true when comes to your personal relationships. Do not under any circumstances engage in a personal relationship with a criminal or those known to associate with criminals. If you're in doubt, ask your superior for advice.
~Do not get drunk or use illegal substances. Keep public drinking to a bare minimum and never engage in any criminal activities. Doing so will expel you from the Constabulary.
~During your Recruit period you're assigned a full member of the Constabulary. You're to assist them in their work, learn from them and show that you're qualified to become a full member.
~Be aware that private life is essentially non-exist as a member of the Constabulary. Any moment you can expect to be called to serve.
Once you've proven you're capable of performing the duties of a Constable and have nothing speaking against you, you become a full member of the Constabulary.

page on OOC Guide to Filing a Crime

When someone approaches you wanting to press charges, you have to create the crime in the system, even if you know it's a false charge. You can also press charges yourself. Only Constables can create a new file in the system.
Once a crime's been created, witnesses and people can give their testimonies and statements by using the system. These are what determines if a suspect is found guilty or not.

page on the OOC Guide to Filing a Crime continued

This is how you do ooc'ly
~Type @crime and a pop-up window will open.
~Here you click the link "File a new crime for investigation]
~In the first field you type in the name of the criminal (if known, if not look further down)
~If there are any accomplices, you add their names to the list. Remember to click the Add bottom so their names are listed.
~In the Name of Crime field you write out all the charges the the file is about.
~In the Description of Crime box you briefly write what the crime is about. Just a few lines, no need to describe in detail, and this is -not- the place to write testimonies etc.
~Click the bottom, File Crime.
~You'll now be able to choose the status type in a drop down menu. The case will be open per default. If there's no suspects, you choose that.
~Further down you can view charges and evidence for your suspects. Choose your suspect on the drop down menu.
~If there are already charges, they'll be listed in blue, which you can click on to read the testimonies and opinions.
~For a new crime you go to the dropdown menu below and pick the appropriate crime. One file can have more crimes.
~You then choose severity. Most crimes will just be normal charge. There are exceptions, so check the List of Current Charges to be sure. Ask a superior if you're in doubt.
~Click the Add crime (or change severity) bottom and you're all set.
~If there's no criminal, you can't add charges and will have to list the crimes in the description field.

page on the OOC Guide to Playing a Constable

Playing a Constable can be a challenge at times, which is why the @crime system was made the way it is.
We have responsibility to create a good playing environment for the criminals, so they don't get punished OOCly for playing and creating stories.
As players we can receive OOC grief from other players, either because we don't arrest the criminals when they know the crime was committed, or because the players of criminals feel we take away their fun of playing.
The punishments have been made to punish characters and not the players. Hence why a fine or short time in prison might seem like a very low punishment.

page on the OOC Guide to Playing a Constable continued

OOCly we are obliged to file any crime that's reported to us. This is to give all players a chance to play out gathering friends and allies to defend their innocence, or convict a guilty. We do not control who gets arrested or not, it all depends on what other players do, eg. filing testimonies and what evidence we find and can file.
It's also for OOC reasons that a murder victim can't testify. This is to avoid someone murdered to come back and instantly point at the guilty person and cause his conviction. The IC excuse is that the memories of those returned isn't reliable. Some lose their memories, some experience visions during their time with S'Allumer, some get confused and so on. Be creative when people ask.
When you encounter grief ICly, refer to the Magistrate who won't issue any punishments or arrests before there's enough evidence and testimonies. Blame him when you feel powerless. You can also encourage people to testify, thereby moving the case forward. It is essentially out of your hands.
If people complain OOC'ly, explain the @crime system to them, teach them how to use it and if that doesn't work, file an assist. The StoryGuides are here to help us deal with any OOC grief you encounter.

page on the Constabulary Oath

To be sworn upon becoming a Deputy
I, Name, do solemnly swear by S'Allumer, to uphold the Laws and Ordinances of the city of Triskellian, serve the public trust, and defend the subjects of His Majesty the Don, without fear, favour, or thought of personal safety; to pursue evil-doers and protect the innocent, laying down my life if necessary in the cause of said durty, so help me S'Allumer. S'Allumer bless the Don.

page on Positions and Ranks

Listed here are a number of positions of responsibility within Triskellian Constabulary. The position of responsibility is not tied into the intrinsic rank that the Constable holds, but is rather tied into their areas of interest and skill.
Paymaster/Clerk
A person or persons who updates documents and keeps all Constable up-to-date on happenings concerning events and guild decisions.
He keeps track of the members and other administrative tasks; including maintaining files and archives, ensuring payment to members and members management.
Envoy
A person or persons who mingles with House and important persons in matters of negotiation.
His responsibilities are mainly the diplomatic relations between the Constabulary and the Houses and guilds, including managing the Triskellian Militia.
Quartermaster
A person or persons who keeps and stores armoury of the Triskellian Constabulary.
The Quartermaster is responsible for ordering weapons and equipment, maintain the armoury and keep track of what has been issued to who.

page on Ranks and Titles

Ranks within the constabulary do correlate with social standing, as those who earn their way up to greater ranks have greater standing.
The general approximations are as follows:
~Deputy is of a similar standing to Freedman
~Guardsman is of a similar standing to Yeoman
~Seargent is of a similar standing to Burgher
~Detective is of a similar standing to Thane
~Aedile is of a similar standing to Gentry
~Sheriff is of a similar standing to Armigerous gentry
~Tribune is of a similar standing to Knight or Dame
~Seargent-Major is of a similar standing to Baronet or Baronetess
~Brigadier is of a similar standing to Baron or Baroness
~Major is of a similar standing to Viscount or Viscountess
~Marshal is of a similar standing to Count or Countess
~Lieutenant General is of a similar standing to Landgrave
~Captain General is of a similar standing to Margrave or Margravine
~Field Marshal is of a similar standing to Marchion or Marchioness
~High Constable is of a similar standing to Duke or Duchess
